title: 115_s62
content: The Act may be cited as the "January 8th National Memorial Act" and includes findings. The tragedy of January 8, 2011, at Congresswoman Gabrielle Gifford's ``Congress on Your Corner'' event resulted in the deaths of 6 people and injury of 13 others, including Congresswoman Giffords. It was the first assassination attempt on a Congressional Member during a constituent meeting. Giffords sustained severe injuries that still affect her today. Gabe Zimmerman was the first Congressional staffer to be killed in the attack. The Arizona community and people worldwide united in support after the assassination attempt on Congresswoman Giffords, with memorial vigils held at the shooting site, the hospital, and her district office. The Tucson community came together in support after the assassination attempt on Congresswoman Giffords, holding memorial vigils at the shooting site, the hospital where victims were treated, and her district office. The January 8th Memorial will honor those who died and showcase the resilience of the community and democracy in the United States. The January 8th National Memorial will honor those who died in the assassination attempt on Congresswoman Giffords and showcase the resilience of the Tucson community and democracy in the United States. The January 8th National Memorial, established by the Secretary of the Interior, is affiliated with the National Park System. The Memorial is defined as the January 8th National Memorial, and the Foundation responsible for its establishment is the Tucson's January 8th Memorial Foundation. The term "map" refers to the January 8 Memorial Site Map. The Secretary of the Interior will establish the January 8th National Memorial as an affiliated area of the National Park System once the Foundation complies with the requirements. The Foundation must establish a trust fund for receiving donations and funding the construction and operation of the Memorial. The Foundation has established a trust fund for receiving donations and managing the construction, operation, and maintenance of the Memorial. The Memorial will be managed by the Foundation and will cease to be affiliated with the National Park System if certain conditions are met. The Foundation will manage the Memorial and is responsible for its construction, operation, maintenance, and management. The Memorial will cease to be affiliated with the National Park System if certain conditions are not met. The map of the Memorial will be available for public inspection at National Park Service offices. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements for technical assistance. The Secretary may provide technical assistance and enter into cooperative agreements with the Foundation for the purpose of providing financial assistance with marketing of the Memorial. Nothing in this Act authorizes the Secretary to acquire property or to use Federal funds for the construction, operation, maintenance, or management of the Memorial. The Secretary, in consultation with the Foundation, shall develop a general management plan for the Memorial. The Secretary, in consultation with the Foundation, shall develop a general management plan for the Memorial and provide a copy to the relevant committees within 3 years of funds being available for the Act or the Memorial's establishment.
